children.value: By default, log messages are written using the various methods available in the

. Lambda Log gives you the ability to use your own custom handler for writing log messages to any place you wish including a third-party service. To create your own log handler, you only need to create an object or class in which implements the various methods used by Lambda Log in the console API.
There are a couple of different ways to do this, but most commonly:
Create a class or object that implements the methods of
Either way you go, the class or object must, at minimum, implement the following methods:
all methods must be synchronous. If you need asynchronous functionality, you may either use
or understand the risk of logs not making it to their destination if the process was to end prior to all asynchronous code executing.
The first method is by creating a new instance of the Console class. One example would be to write logs to a file versus the terminal.
// Create write streams for standard log messages and error messages.
// Set logHandler to a new instance of the Console class.
With this example, your logs will now be written to a file instead of the terminal.
The second method is by creating a custom class or object that implements some of the functions as
. If you want a more complete custom log handler, you may also extend the
class and only override the methods you need to. Let's look at some examples.
// write a file, send to a third-party service, etc.
// and you can still log the message to the terminal:
// write a file, send to a third-party service, etc.
// and you can still log the message to the terminal:
Extend Console class with custom functionality:
// Override error to send logs to a third-party, such as DataDog
// Call the parent method so it's still logged to the terminal:
// Parse message back into an object:
While this is a viable way of sending data to a third-party, it's recommended to use the
